newsitem.title: NORWAY: First gas flows from Heidrun field in Norwegian Sea.
newsitem.headline: First gas flows from Heidrun field in Norwegian Sea.

text.p: Den norske stats oljeselskap AS said on Wednesday first gas had flowed from the Heidrun platform in the Norwegian Sea to the Tjeldbergodden terminal in mid-Norway.

Statoil said Heidrun gas flowed through the 250-km Haltenpipe line and landed at Tjeldbergodden at around 1400 GMT. First gas was delayed by about one week while Statoil replaced a leaking seal in a valve at the receiving station.
"This is a great moment because this marks the opening of a third landing point for Norwegian gas in Norway," a Statoil spokesman said.
Norwegian gas also is landed at Kollsnes and Kaarstoe, both on the west coast.
Haltenpipe has a capacity of two billion cubic metres per year of gas, but initially only part of that will be utilised to feed a new methanol plant at the site.
The methanol plant is due to start production on April 1, 1997.
